Award.AwardTitle: US-Poland International Workshop: Micro and Macro Systems in the Life Sciences, Polish Academy of Sciences, Bedlewo, Poland, June 8-13, 2015
Award.AbstractNarration:
An international workshop entitled, "Micro and Macro Systems in Life Sciences", will take place June 8-13, 2015, at the Stefan Banach International Mathematical Center of the Institute of Mathematics of the Polish Academy of Sciences (IM PAN), in Bedlewo, Poland. The workshop's goals are to bring together applied mathematicians and researchers working on various levels of systems describing phenomena in the life sciences along with some medical doctors and biologists in order to exchange ideas and initiate and promote collaborations.

Understanding problems in the life sciences is a complex issue and involves the analysis of systems on a variety of micro and macro levels. The topics under consideration will include micro and macro systems in cancer biology, multi-scale modeling in physiology, intracellular and intercellular signaling as well as epidemiology and infectious diseases. Over the past years, the list of mathematical tools that has proven useful in analyzing and understanding biological phenomena has grown tremendously. They include new multi-scale techniques in system theory that bridge across different spatial and temporal scales, new directions in dynamical systems, partial differential equation, control theory and computational techniques. The workshop will emphasize the mathematical tools currently available as well as focus on new tools to be developed in order to address current challenges in the life sciences. The workshop will also bring together researchers from the United States and Europe which will facilitate the establishment of more sustained relationships and catalyze new collaborations. A special effort is made to ensure participation of Ph.D. students and postdoctoral researchers who are in the early stages of their careers to expose them to the wealth of possibilities of research in this field and to discuss career and funding opportunities. The workshop will have substantial participation of women and minorities. Proceedings of the workshop will be published as a special issue in the journal "Mathematical Biosciences and Engineering"

POR.DRECONTENT:
The International workshop/conference "Micro and Macro Systems in the Life Sciences" MMSLS, took place June 8-13, 2015 at the Stefan Banach International Mathematical Center of the Institute of Mathematics of the Polish Academy of Sciences, in short IM PAN, in Bedlewo, Poland. Planned originally as a small US-Poland workshop, with the growing interest of participants from other countries, it developedinto a conference size event with 110 participants from 16 countries including the US, Canada, Poland, several countries in Europe, South Africa and Australia  attending and presenting their research. The program included ten plenary talks by internationally renowned mathematicians and scientists active in the fields related to micro and macro systems in life sciences as well as concurrent sessions of invited and contributed talks, a poster session and panel discussions.

The grant from the National Science Foundation partially supported the travel and local expenses of 25 US participants including 12 Ph.D. students, postdoctoral students and junior faculty from the United States. All of them received significant support with some of them full support of their expenses. Modest residual funds left after the conference were used to bring some US participants to the conference Dynamical Systems and Applications IV held June 16-18, 2016 in Lodz, Poland where a special session “Control and Dynamics in Life Sciences” was organized as a follow-up of the MMSLS conference.  Participants who had attended the MMSLS conference presented reports on the research done since the conference in Bedlewo the year before extending the scientific impact of the previous meeting.  

Proceedings of the MMSLS conference in Bedlewo have already been published online and will officially appear as the special issue “Mathematical Methods in Systems Biology and Population Dynamics” Vol. 14, No. 1 of the journal “Mathematical Biosciences and Engineering,” (MBE) in February 2017. Another means of disseminating the findings of the conference is through its website: http://microandmacro.icm.edu.pl/ where slides of all the talks made available by the authors and presenters are available with the intention of  enabling the  exchange of ideas beyond the conference.

Thanks to the efforts of the Organizing Committee, the workshop had a significant participation of junior researchers, graduate students and postdoctoral fellows from the US, Poland and other European countries. The organizers were particularly proud of the success of a poster session which had 17 scienti?c high quality posters presented by graduate students from the US, Poland and other countries.

Overall, with 10 plenary talks and tutorials, 74 regular talks and 17 poster presentations, all the participants had a unique exposure to a variety of interdisciplinary research areas related to micro and macro systems in life sciences. Plenary talks and tutorials covered wide ranges of topics from modeling of atherosclerosis to evaluating the cholesterol risk with free boundary problems to mathematical modeling of cellular cytoskeleton. Separate attention was given to talks devoted to cancer modeling like mathematical aspects of tumor driven anti-angiogenesis or sensitivity of models in combined anticancer therapy. The regular talks were organized in several parallel sessions on diverse topics such as: “Cancer Therapies and Control”, “Models and Methods in Cancer”, “Tumor Immune Interactions”, “Modeling Spread and Treatment of Diseases” “Modeling in Ecology and Evolution” as well as more general, across the board topics like: “Micro Systems: Cellular and Molecular”, “Mathematical Methods in Life Sciences” or “Models in Social and Health Science”. Taking advantage of a good mix of researchers both from the US, Poland and generally Europe as well as of senior and junior researchers, the organizers prepared two panel discussions, “Career and Funding Opportunities in Mathematical Biology” and “Where do we go from there? Challenges and Future Directions for Micro and Macro Systems in Life Sciences.” The panels provided an excellent forum of informal exchange and discussions concerning international and interdisciplinary collaborations, career and funding opportunities and overall trends and directions in the field which were of particular importance for junior researchers.

Besides natural contributions within its discipline, with the variety of mathematical methods employed to the analysis of problems, the conference improved the visibility of mathematical research as part of an overall multi-disciplinary effort taken by researchers from several fields to better understand and solve challenging problems arising in the field of biological sciences, including biomedicine.
